pros: Good experience builder with lots of options for different work environments and schedules. Core values have meaning and the culture is way less toxic even w/lots of new changes some ppl don't grasp.
cons: There just aren't enough staff in mental health to go around. Some toxic ppl just won't leave and company hesitates to terminate.

job_title: Residential Associate I in North Bend, OR
pros: Gain experience in mental health, good pay
cons: You can't think for yourself or speak up

job_title: Facility Administrator in Junction City, OR
pros: Great pay and benefits, low barrier hiring
cons: HR is biased and cruel, martyr-culture, poor training and employee protections

pros: Decent benefits, a few great co-workers dedicated to helping people's mental health struggles.
cons: As mentioned in many other reviews, upper management is toxic and inept; they've just put a lot more energy and resources lately into appearing to care about their employees' well-being, but the truth is they view all non-executive members as expendable and will always back upper management without exception. The Outpatient program has done a nosedive in terms of quality and general coherence over the past 6 months due to change in leadership. Unfortunately the repercussions are felt throughout all levels of the program, with infighting, favoritism, and lack of accountability all contributing to abysmal morale and shockingly poor clinical results. You can't just throw money at a problem or program and expect it to get better if the same ineffectual, performative leadership are repeatedly rewarded and given a pass. ColumbiaCare should, and can, do better.

pros: Collaborative work environment amongst leadership, good communication and organization seems organized overall. Pay increases are done equitably (lowest paid staff are given raises first, as opposed to other places I've worked for where everyone gets a percentage raise at the same time, resulting in management getting huge raises and front line staff getting small ones). DEIJ efforts are collaborative and reasonable. There is acknowledgement of past toxic culture at the agency that upper management is attempting to shift. CEO seems genuine in efforts to create positive change. As a mid manager I feel I am given enough autonomy and direction in my role to be effective and create positive changes in my department. I also like the core values of Columbiacare and how the company does not seem to just talk about them but embrace them in certain ways.
cons: As always with non-profit mental health, pay for front line staff could be better. Copays with benefits are high with BCBS and Kaiser plan has high deductible, though they do help with HSA which sounded like a headache to get reimbursement for. Only certain roles (QMHP and management) get funding for training while other roles (QMHA, Peers, etc) get nothing.

job_title: Care Support Specialist in Medford, OR
pros: Decent benefits package Ongoing training More care toward employees than previously cared before pandemic
cons: Claims Diversity, Equity & Inclusion, yet only seems to employee a predominantly White and local employee base that claims to have DEI knowledge, yet clearly has had little contact with non-White cultures. In fact, they had employees in the training process actively share they could not relate to clients who experience ghosts and spirits as real and would sooner say those are unreal and the client is experiencing psychosis. Not culturally-competent or understanding and maintains a facade of competence when they do not have the authority to measure that. There are clearly institutional problems that are not transparently discussed and because of that leads to a toxic positivity culture.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Medford, OR
pros: Great benefits, the culture, diversity, equity, inclusion, the Core Values.
cons: Therapists seem to turnover frequently

job_title: Quality Mental Health Associate (QMHA) in Eugene, OR
pros: Team approach, autonomy, and growth opportunities
cons: Not a lot of cons.

job_title: Events & Special Projects Coordinator in Medford, OR
pros: Great benefits, Nice administrative offices
cons: Salary could be more competitive

job_title: Residential Associate I in Junction City, OR
pros: Management is laid-back, approachable, and accepts feedback. A perk is the Wellness program that offers a reimbursement of 600.00 yr on whatever you choose to spend the money on for your wellbeing. HR seems efficient, and get back to you quickly.
cons: You trade time for money. It's not a job where you are actually helping to make a difference with the residents who basically stay in their rooms, so low interactions, and seriously boring. There is not a set structure, routine or consistency to count on, so it's easy to feel frustrated, especially for newer staff. Eventually you figure out that staff are there to clean and cook. You are expected to take 30 min lunch break, (or get written up), but your choices are to sit in your car or in a storage closet, so in order to avoid a write up, staff clock in and out without ever leaving the floor. The facility RN, seems to have control over management and makes decisions over what happens. Management turns a blind eye to staff who get high or drink on the job, "as long as it's off camera" as per admin, which could have been kidding or not, but seems to allow discretion, as evidenced by staff's behavior being tolerated.

job_title: QUALIFIED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL in Gresham, OR
pros: I enjoyed working at Columbia Care, they care about their employees and offer many benefits, both onsurance and health incentives such as health/ fitness related contests, stories, goals, etc. Lots of different facilities.
cons: Cons include low pay, constant work, job stress.

pros: Many good people have been hired at Columbiacare.
cons: None of the great people stay due to the toxicity of there narcissistic CEO, HR dept, nepotism, and condescending attitude towards the backbone of the company, there field staff.  I can’t describe the attitude of those at the administration offices in Medford. These people look down their noses at 90 percent of their workforce, paying low wages for ridicules hours while the CEO takes in a half a million a year. Maybe someone will take notice at JC Connect  and give the contract to a company that isn’t up to its ears in corporation . They are a hate filled bunch preaching that they are moral upstanding citizens. It’s truly  sad.

pros: The opportunity to work independently. Friendly atmosphere.
cons: Often put in compromising or dangerous positions with clients in the community. Unclear expectations from upper management.

review_title: Learned loads about the industry and met wonderful people

pros: Nothing positive to share about this company.

job_title: Quality Mental Health Associate (QMHA) in Medford, OR

review_title: A Review from  a Disillusioned Employee
pros: Base pay for QMHAs is decent. Not the highest, but also not the lowest in the area. Easy to pick up hours as on-call staff, with the potential to quickly transition to part-time or full-time. Awarded training and retention bonuses when applicable.
cons: Middle management is pretty hit or miss. Under short-lived good management, my facility had a hardworking, committed team of mental health professionals. The program itself was far from flawless, but it had great potential as it worked to find its footing in the community. Employee feedback was valued and encouraged, and good work ethic was acknowledged and rewarded. After a regime change, everything fell apart. The main office in Medford refused to acknowledge the consistent failures and inadequacies of their new program directors, who were driving away long-term employees. Policies were enforced selectively, and employees were routinely degraded and devalued, then encouraged to leave when they voiced their concerns. Management demanded unreasonable and unsafe work conditions. Employees were reprimanded for not taking on last-minute 12+ hour shifts. There were several instances of client-on-staff violence, which was belittled or was entirely ignored by management. Management was exceptionally accommodating to employees with poor job performance depending on their level of favor with their supervisors. Unethical behavior from management was often swept under the rug.

job_title: Accounting Specialist III in Medford, OR
pros: Understanding, accommodating, great work environment
cons: Low human contact, but this was due to covid

job_title: Direct Care Professional in Medford, OR
pros: The clients we serve make it barely tolerable
cons: The bosses who dictate make it feel like a prison

pros:
This company is great to work for. They have amazing benefits, are very accommodating to "life" situations, and very eager to promote within. What they do for the community is incredible and even though you may not work directly with the clients, it's still a very rewarding job. 

There medical benefits are incredible and super low cost; they have a Wellness Benefit that will reimburse you up to $400 a year towards wellness items like fitness classes, camping equipment, spa treatments...anything that helps with your whole health wellness. They also offer a lot of training regardless of your position, so you gain a lot of mental health knowledge.
cons: Management wears a lot of hats and is usually extremely busy, so it can be difficult to get assignments finished up in a timely manner because they are out of the office, or tied up doing other things, which can put a lot of stress back on the individuals assisting them; but I understand. Upper management is super passionate about their jobs so they are just busy busy!

review_title: Successful in spite of Executive Management
pros: Amazingly caring professional staff. Facilities are clean and well maintained. Decent benefit package. Company is growing at a very fast rate.
cons: Good ole boy system with preference given to family members and friends of executive management. Salaries determined by relationships, not merit based. Lack of transparency in decision-making. Lavish conferences held yearly for administrators with money that could have been better spent on programs. Looks more like a real estate business than a mental health provider. Comment about hiring people they like without even having a job description is true, which does not promote trust or loyalty in current employees who want to advance.

review_title: Loved working with the residents, however corporate attitude really made it difficult to stay.
job_title: Assistant Administrator in Coos Bay, OR
pros:
Mental health services are truly needed in OR. If you enjoy being part of this, it's a fabulous opportunity to put your skills to work and make a difference in peoples' lives.
Some good bennies if you are upper management. Great employees to work with. I truly met some of the nicest and most caring people while working there. Columbia Care is blessed to have such good employees.
cons:
Horrible corporate office. They only hire relatives regardless of their abilities. While they are fabulous with the rights of the mentally ill they do nothing to prevent abuse of their employees.
Columbia Care really has suffered growing pains and unfortunately it seems their focus has shifted to the almighty dollar. I asked multiple times for help with a dictatorish manager who was truly abusive to employees and it repeatedly fell on deaf ears.

review_title: Horrible administrator at Fairview Firs in Fairview 2014
job_title: Residential Associate I in Fairview, OR
pros: Difficult to find any, some of the clients are nice. I liked a few of the staff.
cons:
Fairview Firs

I had another co worker who was jealous of my skills and she constantly stirred up trouble. The administrator was rude and not kind to his employees in the least. They talk behind your back and only look at faults. They treated you as if  your replaceable. The head nurse employees dreading when she came in. I could never pin point if but someone should look into how they handle their money something crooked was going on while I was there but I can not define this. There were some nice staff but to be honest I would never apply to work at that particular program. I am not able to speak for other programs within the company. I had horrible anxiety when there but now that I quit its gone. Simple not a good place. Do not trust anyone there for your best interest at heart.  It required a lot to be able to work there credential wise yet they still treat you badly. I once again would steer far from this place. I worked there about a year. With 18 years experience in social work and a psychology degree.

pros: Grinding educational training, but good training, somewhat relevant. Staff are qualified, skilled in many areas and are willing to share their experiences if management would remove their own boots from staff-necks.
cons: If you have further education and/or experience than an assistant admin, they are threatened, and you are the enemy. Any promises of further success at hiring by the admin, is quickly diminished. Ask a question and you’re gone. Assistants make small change of those they perceive as a possible replacement. Creativity is declared a waste of time. which causes the leaders to clamp down on what is permitted even further. This leadership style is focused more on retaining power and control than expanding opportunities for others.

pros: State work within a private non profit. Basically take a well paid union state job, have a bunch of ex state workers start a non profit company so they can skim off a large salary for themselves and pay collage educated employees less than a living wage doing intense work directly with mentally ill clients. In smaller town this same work is union and the homes are ran by the state.
cons: Hard nearly impossible work. Mangers relentlessly demanding more and more from over worked under paid staff.

review_title: Great direct care employees, good program administrators, okay agency.
pros:
The Good: Overall, the agency is very client-focused.  From direct care to local management through the administrative offices, when a client requires more services, greater attention and changes to their care, absolutely everyone is dedicated to make sure that person gets what they need as quickly as possible.  Direct care staff work exceptionally hard to maintain a high level of care to the residents.  They are professional, caring and dedicated to improving the lives of some very challenging people.  The facilities are very well maintained.  With the Portland Metro area, CCS has a dedicated maintenance team that handles repairs and landscaping.  The programs are well-lit, well decorated and there’s a strong effort to make the facilities as home-like and welcoming as possible.

Neither Good/Bad: Their benefits are largely in-line with other agencies within the city and state.  They have self insured vision and dental benefits, which requires paying out of pocket in advance.  If you live in the Portland area, you are given a number of health insurance options.  If your program is rural, you may be stuck with a single, more expensive option.  The agency matches to the 403b at a much higher rate than I’ve participated previously.
cons:
The Bad: ColumbiaCare Services is based out of Medford, whereas the overwhelming majority of its programs are in the Portland Metro area.  The vast majority of the agency’s executive administration, clinical management, HR, support services and billing are in Medford.  Because of this, there is a culture of very poor communication and oversight from a distance at all levels.  Everyone outside of the administrative office is overwhelmingly aware of this on a cellular level.  Everyone can tell in which ways it adversely affects everything from the culture of the agency, expectations placed onto local area program administrators through how direct care staff feel supported.  The agency has attempted to manage this distance by back filling in middle management positions, staff and out-of-the-way facilities.  At best, perhaps its trickle down effect will somehow aid the clients.  At worst, the middle manager hired to project manage from afar is unreasonably distant and introduction to her peers is a powerpoint filled with pictures of her dog.  Overall, there are several byproducts which the agency seemingly doesn’t care about or at least, fails at responding to appropriately.

Direct care staff are under-supported.  Any wage changes made by the agency are most often a reaction to how far out of line they may be paying their staff.  People most often leave their jobs here not because the clients are difficult or the program culture doesn’t match - It’s because almost anywhere else starts at a higher rate of pay.  In this economy, the bottom line is how much they pay and because of this, finding applicants is very difficult.  Merit raises rarely happen and if they do, it’s a minimal change.  At their anniversary with the agency, staff are supposed to receive an annual review and depending on their performance, raises can be recommended by the program admin.  If the admin is overwhelmed by their job, these reviews can be completed and possessed months late, which prevents direct care staff from their deserved bump in pay.

Local area administrators are under-supported.  The programs that receive the majority of attention and support are those that are starting up (makes sense), programs that are failing on some level (makes sense) and those whose administrators are favored by the admin office (doesn’t make sense).  Typically these favorited admins are toxic to their direct care staff, unknowingly undermine attempts at programs successes and have little interaction and knowledge of their clients.  Outside of these examples, all of program administrators face major burnout.  This can be from the lack of staffing options which forces them to work overnight shifts, having to cover communication from theirs and other facilities 24/7 and other day to day challenges.  Their exec-level supervisors have absolutely no interest in hearing it.  Monthly supervision with the administrative office is an opportunity to make sure the program isn’t facing a lawsuit, being shut down or facing a catastrophic issue.  It’s supervision in name only and doesn’t leave the local admin feeling successfully listened to or supported.

The Ugly: This agency wastes a lot of money!  Previously, CCS has administrator conferences twice a year at a cost of tens of thousands of dollars each.  Local area admins would be put up in reasonably nice hotels for days a time, treated to expensive banquet dinners with open bars and would be run through powerpoint presentations and lectures by senior administration.  Through expansive clip-show Apple-made feel good movies, the conference reads more like a cheerleading rally to make the administrative office feel like its making an impact.  Program admins more often feel their time is being wasted.  As nice as it may be to participate and be wined/dined, almost none of it is necessary.  CCS’ administrators are typically down to earth people who’d rather be left to do their job than be separated from the facilities and family.  Rather than spend tens of thousands on these events, the agency should set up similar events for direct care staff, such as a company-wide field day and bbq, direct staff specific catered retreats or appreciation days.  They do so much extraordinary work and rarely receive the thanks they deserve!

Lastly, the executive level team receive extraordinarily high compensation.  In 2015, Trillium’s total revenue was $25 million and their CEO made $274k as their annual salary.  In that same year, CCS’ total revenue was a little under $24 million and the president’s annual salary was more than $430k.  The other exec team members’ compensation isn’t as high as this, but its consistently higher than other comparable providers.  As all of these organizations are non-profits, everyone can easily examine and compare details by Googling “propublica columbiacare services”.  As with all non-profits, the 990 forms are publicly available.

job_title: Residential & Supportive Housing in Portland, OR
pros: Client-focused. Quality facilities. Great co-workers. A large variety of programs allows for different experiences; there are some great leaders and teams.
cons: Administration can be closed to feedback, dismissive, defensive.... Punitive management.

job_title: Residential Associate II in Portland, OR
pros: The Good: Overall, I think the spirit of the agency is worthwhile.  ColumbiaCare takes pride in accepting clients no one else wants to.  The agency is also taking on a number of projects that are out of traditional residential care and into community assistance (Supportive Housing -> Apartments for stable, mentally ill clients -and- Intensive Case Management -> Hospital diversion).  The agency seems to be one of the only ones out there growing and diversifying, so there's no lack of opportunity.
cons:
The Bad: Because of how litigious former employees can be, the agency acts very conservatively with toxic employees, from line staff through administrators.  In reading other reviews, other line staff have run up against working with senior staff and administrators who were/are poor leaders.  In working at half dozen different sites, there's no shortage of stories of bad administrators - One who fired almost half of their staff upon being hired, being backed up by HR and were then themselves found to be the cause of the problem; one who refused to complete years-worth of treatment plans and instead would sext with their out of town boyfriend, while letting sensitive paperwork stack in drifts around his office. Line staff are easier to build a case against firing, especially if other co-workers don't work well with them.  It's harder (and more likely expensive) to attempt the same with administrators.

The Ugly: The corporate culture has a huge blind spot and communication divide because it's based in Medford and more than 85% of the facilities are in the Portland-Metro area.  That separation and its cascading effect touches everything from hiring/training, facility cultures, hiring problematic staff and then managing them from a distance, attitudes towards line staff, "being visible", etc.  The agency HQ directs itself without any good feedback on how its decisions effect others and the end effect is ignorance at best, lack of care/disregard at worst.  Most communication from them eventually sounds like disingenuous cheerleading, sending emails and feel-good videos that look to back-pat more than celebrate front lines successes.  As line staff, this feels like "Medford" is remarkably out of touch with everything and the only people we can count on are our local admins, who themselves are doing well but are regularly rolling their eyes at what is asked of them -or- administrators who kiss up to their supervisors from afar, while slowly eroding all trust in their line staff.

review_title: Company needs to look forward and get current with research
pros: They manage to hire really caring hard working people. Some of the most dedicated employees I have ever met.
cons: HR is behind on knowing the law, and does not support the employee. I hate to use incompetent but  in many cases it has proven to be so.

pros:
-A hefty wellness reimbursement to use for things such as massages, dance classes, a bike.
-Co workers
-Supportive Housing: this was a work environment that fostered creativity, collaboration, and allowed for the acquisition of numerous transferable skills. Most people developed great advocacy having to do a moderate amount of case management and care coordination. Your interactions with other professionals and your team was valued and I never felt communication was lacking. I was fortunate enough to have good management.  I felt there was a lot of opportunity for growth and the performance feedback was invaluable. The work was important and necessary to help clients remain in the community. There was frequent exposure to crisis situations, which further led to developing creative problem solving skills. The depth and amount of crisis remains unparalleled in other programs. There was a real sense of community that remains lacking in residential programs. It's unfortunate that all but one program lost funding.
cons:
-Demoralizing management.
 Communication to a certain group of staff/shifts became virtually non existant. Staff morale has dropped amongst the majority and there exists palpable tension.  This site is known by on calls to have the worst staff-management morale in the metro area. Effective leaders support, encourage, and collaborate with their staff. This doesn't occur outside of short, sometimes bitter email exchanges. Communication about client changes/updates was lacking.  There was no real direction or support to those that didn't have direct access to management and if things weren't done correctly, you'd receive no feedback on how you could have handled a situation differently, just a disapproving tone. Staff aren't learning or growing. It's a stagnant environment fueled by fear of reprimand and a great many staff don't feel supported or valued. There are great programs in the company that operate as a cohesive unit, where management works well with all shifts, but this hasn't been one of them for quite some time.

review_title: High ethical standard, expanding too fast.
pros: Job security. Major benefit. There's not a lot of employment available in the Portland Metro area, but working in residential mental health (if you can qualify) certainly has job security. Extensive ongoing training through the company, and overtime available. The benefits are really good.
cons: The company is expanding rapidly, but there's not a lot of opportunity for advancement in the company. Be sure you negotiate a good starting wage, because wage increases are minimal unless you move into a position that has a lot more responsibility.

review_title:
Staff Are Not Valued, Toxic Leadership Goes Unchecked,
Apparent After 3 Years of Service
job_title: IT Help Desk Specialist in Medford, OR
pros:
There are some great people at the company, but the good ones do not last long.
The company mission is noble, but poorly executed.
cons:
There is extremely high turnover and the reasons for it, along with received feedback are ignored.
At the time of writing this, there are over a dozen open positions on the internal job board for the Medford area.
Instead of making an effort to create a healthy environment and appreciate employees, their main focus is opening as many facilities as possible, and becoming slum lords of healthcare in Oregon. The leadership is toxic, and there is not much faith in the ineffective human resources department. There is an obvious good ole boy system at work.

review_title: Company is getting too big for its britches.
pros:
Company philosophy is great and shines through at the programmatic level.
Company sends a great deal of money on the clients and ensures they have the best living situation possible.
High attention to detail.
Great client care when it comes to helping them with ADL's.
Company accepts technological advancements quicker than other organizations in the Portland Metro area.
Nonprofit that makes sure employees don't feel pressured to make money and bill or get to the magic dollar amount.
cons:
Strong "Maybe this isn't the right fit for you" culture... If you have any opinion outside what upper management thinks then the first thought is to get rid of you. They simply say, "You clearly aren't moving west with us." and drop you.
Strong aversion towards evidence-based practices and providing treatment services.
Management is very clique-y and if you are not part of the in-crowd then you will be slowly shut out.
Company philosophy and treatment approach has been unchanged since the organization's creation. They seem to see it as a selling point, but ignoring 15+ years of research and change in the field cannot lead to good client care.
Programs do the bare minimum to survive state audits.
Company is growing but appears to have no clear direction. Most of the growth appears to be opportunity based with little forethought into how it fits into the big picture.
Programs are given free reign with little oversight, which is great if you have a good admin, but can make bad admins especially toxic to work for.

pros: It was very hard work and it takes a special type. The pay could be much better considering the work load. It is very challenging to deal with.
cons: It was very hard work and it takes a special type. The pay could be much better considering the work load.It is very challenging to deal with.

pros: ColumbiaCare Services was founded on a few simple principles that guide the organization as it provides services for clients. One of the sayings I heard over the years, that resonated with me the most, was from the late Executive Director Bob Becket. He often said, “when in doubt, do the right thing”. In my almost three years at ColumbiaCare, I have held two positions in two separate programs and I cannot think of a single instance in which the leadership or staff failed to follow Bob’s guidance. I have worked through countless tough situations with clients and have always seen the staff and leadership put the need of the client above everything else. As a front-line staff member, I have been given incredible support by the leadership. I have never felt like I couldn’t come to my supervisor with concerns. The few times I did need to voice a concern, I was shown genuineness and felt validated while we worked through the issue together. I have felt empowered and respected by leadership when given the freedom to case manage the way that works for me and my clients without micro-managing. One of the most unique elements of ColumbiaCare is the staff’s desire to see our clients get better, no matter what their job is. Outside of direct client care, our maintenance staff is passionate about maintenance because they know that the work they do improves the people’s lives in our programs. Our IT staff work quickly and effectively knowing that each moment a system is down can have a negative impact on the services we provide. Seeing everyone’s passion to help our clients from the clinical staff to the nonclinical is remarkable. ColumbiaCare started as a job for me but has developed into being part of my family and who I am. I would recommend ColumbiaCare to anyone that desires purpose in employment and the opportunity to grow personally and professionally.
cons: As mentioned by other reviewers, the higher-level managers/administrators wear many hats, and have required travel, and that can cause some delays in communication. As someone that works best with little to no supervision, I prefer the management style that trusts my experience and education to help my clients free from micro-managing, but I could see it being an issue in other programs where staff may need a little more support.

pros: I have worked for ColumbiaCare Services for over 5 years, and I'm extremely happy with the organization and my position. If you work hard, there are many opportunities for career advancement and pay increases. Overall, I feel I have been treated very well, and I look forward to being with the company for a long time.
cons: Sometimes certain people are held to a different set of standards than others, but that is to be expected at any workplace.

review_title: Great philosophy for client treatment but crappy management.
job_title: Residential Associate II in Portland, OR
pros: Always available to hire.  Good treatment philosophy
cons: Most unprofessional company around.  Managment talks about each others faults and individual staff problems including personal informatoin to everyone and anyone in the company.

job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Wilsonville, OR
pros: Good environment for residents. Nice buildings and houses.
cons: Not a good company for Peer Support Specialists. The job description for residential associate and peer support is identical. Oregon peer specialists are not trained and certified to cook, clean and pass meds. That is 80 per cent of the job. Other 20 percent is driving. No peer support duties.

pros: This is  a great company to work for.  They give bonuses and do a lot of training.
cons: There aren't any.  It is a 24 hour facility,  You have to work different shifts, ,hoilidays and week-ends.

pros: Good Pay and long lunch break
cons: No Vacation but long lunch break

job_title: Residential Associate in North Bend, OR
pros: Base pay is pretty good.
cons: Upper management does not care to listen when line staff bring up the erratic behavior of facility level administrators.

pros: Most line staff are great.
cons: Dog eat dog environment. Employees encouraged to report on each other. "Nonprofit" with a CEO who makes $450,000 a year and pays staff $13 an hour.
